<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 71, 881, 89]]<|/det|>
A student investigates the period of a pendulum. Fig. 1.1 and Fig. 1.2 show the arrangement.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[210, 98, 460, 330]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[581, 98, 784, 330]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[312, 344, 381, 362]]<|/det|>
<label>Fig. 1.1</label>

<|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[616, 344, 687, 362]]<|/det|>
<label>Fig. 1.2</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 375, 146, 394]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 375, 851, 393]]<|/det|>
The student measures the distance \(d\) between the bottom of the clamp and the floor.

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[551, 415, 912, 437]]<|/det|>
\[d = \mathrm{120.0cm}\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 452, 655, 470]]<|/det|>
This distance \(d\) remains constant throughout the experiment.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 483, 579, 501]]<|/det|>
He adjusts the length \(l\) of the pendulum to \(70.0 \text{cm}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 514, 920, 547]]<|/det|>
Calculate the distance \(x\) between the centre of the pendulum bob and the floor. Record the value of \(x\) in the first row of Table 1.1. [1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 560, 146, 579]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 560, 920, 593]]<|/det|>
The student displaces the bob slightly and releases it so that it swings. Fig. 1.2 shows one complete oscillation of the pendulum.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 606, 920, 624]]<|/det|>
He measures, and records in the first row of Table 1.1, the time \(t\) for 10 complete oscillations.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 637, 180, 656]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 637, 920, 670]]<|/det|>
Calculate, and record in the first row of Table 1.1, the period \(T\) of the pendulum. The period is the time for one complete oscillation. [1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 682, 180, 701]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 682, 631, 701]]<|/det|>
Calculate, and record in the first row of Table 1.1, \(T^2\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 683, 920, 701]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[144, 714, 180, 733]]<|/det|>
<label>(iii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 714, 559, 733]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 715, 920, 733]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[546, 190, 917, 214]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[541, 288, 920, 308]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[544, 390, 917, 415]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[546, 435, 917, 460]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 483, 920, 523]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[541, 551, 920, 571]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 72, 710, 89]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 102, 747, 120]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 73, 94, 91]]<|/det|>
<label>4</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 72, 920, 106]]<|/det|>
A student investigates the rate of cooling, in air, of heated blocks made of different metals. The temperature of each block is increased by placing it in hot water.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 119, 920, 152]]<|/det|>
Plan an experiment to investigate how the rate of cooling depends on the metal from which each block is made.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 166, 537, 183]]<|/det|>
The following apparatus is available to the student:

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 196, 918, 228]]<|/det|>
cylindrical blocks of different metals, each with a hole for a thermometer, as shown in Fig. 4.1 a thermometer.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 243, 740, 260]]<|/det|>
Other apparatus normally available in a school laboratory can also be used.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 274, 324, 291]]<|/det|>
In your plan, you should:

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[134, 305, 470, 322]]<|/det|>
· list any additional apparatus required

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[134, 336, 920, 368]]<|/det|>
· explain briefly how you would carry out the investigation, including the measurements you would take

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[134, 382, 512, 400]]<|/det|>
· state the key variables to be kept constant

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[134, 414, 920, 446]]<|/det|>
· draw a suitable table, with column headings, to show how you would display your readings (you are not required to enter any readings in the table)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[134, 460, 662, 477]]<|/det|>
· explain how you would use the results to reach a conclusion.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[351, 488, 640, 603]]<|/det|>
